title: RL31837
content: During the 1929 Depression, rural residents faced low incomes and living standards. The Federal Emergency Relief Administration, Farm Security Administration, and Work Projects Administration provided assistance to rural families. Post-World War II, rural poverty, especially among farmers, remained a concern. The Eisenhower Administration initiated a Rural Development Program in 1955 to help low-income farmers. The focus on farms and rural poverty continued through the War on Poverty in the 1960s. The 1980s farm financial crisis and economic dislocation in rural America brought rural structural change to the forefront of policy concerns. The decline of farming and manufacturing jobs has widened the gap between rural and urban areas. Key federal rural policy focuses on housing, employment, human capital, poverty, medical care, and infrastructure development. The rural population has decreased over the past decade. According to the U.S. Census, as of July 2012, approximately 46.2 million people (14.6% of the U.S. population) lived in rural areas, down from about 16% in 2000. Rural areas have seen declines in population, including in retirement and recreation areas. Manufacturing accounts for 22% of rural private sector earnings and 11% of rural jobs. Farming remains a major focus in congressional debates on rural policy. Title VI of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 (P.L. 110-246) addresses agriculture and manufacturing issues in rural areas, aiming to help them compete globally. Omnibus farm bills are key legislative tools for rural development, reauthorizing USDA programs. Congress uses these bills to address emerging rural issues and reauthorize rural programs. The USDA rural development mission agencies aim to enhance rural communities by providing financial and technical resources. Three agencies, established in 1994, focus on rural housing, business-cooperatives, and utilities. Congress has enacted various laws to address rural policies and residents' needs, such as the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. The Rural Electrification Act of 1936 was crucial for providing electricity and telephone service to rural America. The National Commission on Rural Poverty was established in 1966, leading to various loan and grant programs for rural social welfare. The 1972 Rural Development Act marked a significant milestone in congressional concern for rural policy. New rural development legislation typically amends major authorizing statutes to address the needs of rural communities. The Rural Electrification Act of 1936 (P.L. 92-419) established the Rural Electrification Administration (REA) to provide subsidized loans and grants for electrifying rural areas. Cooperatives, tax-exempt entities owned by members, were utilized to expand access to electricity and telephone services in rural communities. The Rural Electrification Act of 1936 established the Rural Electrification Administration (REA) to provide subsidized loans and grants for electrifying rural areas. By the mid-1950s, rural homes had electricity matching suburban levels, and by 1975, over 99% of farms were electrified. Telephone penetration in rural areas reached 90% by the mid-1970s and has remained around 95% for the past 20 years. The REA was replaced by the Rural Utilities Service (RUS) in 1994, administering rural electric programs. The Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act of 1972, also known as the ConAct, serves as the authorizing statute for USDA rural development programs. Title V of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act of 1972 designated the USDA as the lead agency for coordinating nationwide rural development programs, including the Community Facility Loan program, Rural Business and Industry Loan program, and Rural Business Enterprise Grant program. This legislation expanded the USDA's role in addressing multi-state, state, sub-state, and local rural development needs. The omnibus 1990 farm bill amended the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act of 1972 to establish the Rural Development Administration (RDA) in USDA. The RDA absorbed non-farm FmHA functions and established provisions for rural economic development revolving funds, a Rural Business Investment Fund, and local revolving funds. It also set up a delivery system for certain rural development programs, including providing rural water and waste services. Established a delivery system for rural development programs, including rural water and waste facilities. Amended various acts to authorize lending for water and waste projects, establish wastewater treatment programs, provide emergency community water assistance grants, and enhance rural community access to telecommunications. Also supported rural businesses by establishing technical assistance units, deferring loan payments, and promoting rural incubator funds. Title VIII authorized the first rural Empowerment Zones and Enterprise Communities (EZ/ECs) to revitalize low-income rural communities and attract private sector investment. The program was administered by USDA for rural areas and HUD for urban areas. By December 1994, three rural Empowerment Zones and 30 rural Enterprise Communities were named. Additional EZs and ECs were added in 1997 and 2001. Tax incentives for EZ Communities were extended until 2013, but the rural EC program expired in December 2009. The rural Empowerment Zones and Enterprise Communities program expired in December 2009. USDA Rural Development is currently not authorized to designate any new zones or communities. The legislation also reorganized rural development into the Rural Housing Service, Rural Business-Cooperative Service, and Rural Utilities Service, abolishing the Rural Electrification Administration. The 1996 omnibus farm bill abolished the Rural Electrification Administration and established the Rural Utilities Service as its successor. Title VII of the bill focused on Rural Development, including initiatives for telemedicine and distance learning services in rural areas, increased grant amounts for water and waste facilities, and revised the definition of "rural" areas for eligibility for grants and loans. The 2002 farm bill established mandatory funding for a Fund for Rural America, including the Rural Community Advancement Program (RCAP) for rural research, economic development, and housing. Title VI authorized new rural development initiatives with mandatory funding through the Commodity Credit Corporation. The Rural Strategic Investment Fund established a National Board on Rural America providing $100 million in planning grants. The Rural Business Investment Program offered $100 million in loan guarantees and subsidies for Rural Business Investment corporations. Enhanced Access to Broadband Service allocated $10 million-$20 million per year for grants and loans. Rural Local Television Broadcast Signal Loan Guarantees authorized $80 million. Value-added Agricultural Product Market Development Grants provided $40 million per year, with a 5% set-aside for organic production. In FY2003, $15 million was allocated for 10 new Agriculture Innovation Centers to assist value-added agricultural businesses. The Rural America Infrastructure Development Account authorized $360 million for water and waste water applications. The Rural Firefighters and Emergency Personnel Grant Program received $10 million per year from FY2003-FY2007 for training. Funding for these programs was blocked between FY2004 and FY2007, but the 2008 farm bill reauthorized some programs through annual appropriations. The 2008 omnibus farm bill, funded through annual appropriations, expired in September 2012 but was extended through December 2013. Title VI of the bill expanded broadband access in rural areas, created new assistance and investment programs, and authorized funding for water and wastewater projects. Some programs from the 2002 farm bill were reauthorized with discretionary funding in the 2008 bill. The 2008 farm bill reauthorized the Value-Added Product Grants Program with $15 million of annual mandatory funding and $40 million of annual discretionary funding. It also modified the definition of "rural" to include "areas rural in character," allowing certain rural areas to be eligible for USDA loans and grants. Special designations were made for San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Honolulu, Hawaii, and criteria were established for defining rural areas contiguous to urban areas. Other new provisions included loans and loan guarantees for locally or regionally produced agricultural food products. The 2008 farm bill reauthorized the Value-Added Product Grants Program with funding and modified the definition of "rural" to include "areas rural in character." It also included provisions for loans and loan guarantees for locally or regionally produced agricultural food products. Additionally, new programs were introduced to support economically disadvantaged microentrepreneurs and increase equity capital availability in rural areas. Regional economic development commissions were also established. The 2014 farm bill reauthorized and amended various loan and grant programs in key areas such as broadband, rural utilities, business, and community development. It extended funding for USDA Rural Development programs through FY2018, encouraging private or cooperative lenders to provide financing for water and waste water projects. The Agricultural Act of 2014 reauthorized and amended loan and grant programs for rural development, encouraging private lenders to provide financing. It included provisions for technical assistance, loan guarantees, data collection on project economic effects, simplified funding applications, and consolidated business programs into Business Development grants. Mandatory spending was allocated for rural development loans, grants, and Value-Added Product Grants. The law amended the definition of rural areas, raised the population threshold for eligibility, and reauthorized funding for programs under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. It also established new procedures for the Access to Broadband Telecommunications Services in Rural Areas Program and authorized a Gigabit Network Pilot Program for high-speed broadband service. A new Gigabit Network Pilot Program for high-speed broadband service was authorized at $10 million for each fiscal year FY2014-FY2018. The law also authorized a new Rural Energy Savings Program to fund loans for energy efficiency measures. Various loan and grant programs are administered by USDA Rural Development agencies for rural housing, business, and utilities. Rural areas face challenges with substandard housing, poverty, and lack of affordable housing. The Housing Act aimed to address poverty and inadequate rural housing in America. It highlighted issues such as the prevalence of mobile homes, high housing costs for rural households, lack of clean water access, and limited mortgage credit. The legislation emphasized the importance of providing every American with a decent home and suitable living environment, especially in post-World War II when housing shortages were prevalent. The Housing Act played a significant role in shaping U.S. urban and suburban areas, influencing state and local policies on housing, social welfare, race relations, and economic development. It established housing as a central policy focus by financing slum clearance, increasing FHA mortgage insurance, and committing to building new public housing units. The Act aimed to address poverty and inadequate rural housing, emphasizing the importance of providing every American with a decent home, especially during post-World War II housing shortages. The Housing Act addressed shortages and low-quality housing in rural America by authorizing the Farmers Home Administration to grant mortgages for rural single-family houses. It provided financial assistance for rural property purchase, construction, insurance on loans, and rental housing for farm workers. The USDA Rural Housing Service now insures housing loans for home purchases, repairs, and rental housing development. The 1968 Housing Act aimed to address housing issues for low-income families by authorizing programs like the Section 235 homeownership program. It set a goal of creating 26 million new housing units, with 6 million reserved for low-income individuals. The act also established various other housing-related programs and agencies, including the Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae). Title V of the 1983 Housing Act amends previous housing acts to require a percentage of rural housing loans to be available for very low-income individuals. It authorizes loans for manufactured homes meeting safety standards and includes programs for homeownership and rental housing without requiring annual reauthorization. Budget authorization is in terms of loan subsidies and authority. The Housing Act of 1983 requires a percentage of rural housing loans for very low-income individuals and authorizes loans for manufactured homes. Housing loan subsidies are transfers from the Treasury to lenders to provide loans at reduced interest rates. Loan authority refers to the total value of all loans made under a program. Funding for Rural Housing Service programs comes from the Rural Housing Insurance Fund through direct loans, guaranteed loans, and grants. The USDA's main housing loan program offers guaranteed loans with federal protection for private lenders in case of borrower default. Grants are direct funds given through competitions. The program helps low-income individuals buy, build, repair, or renovate homes in rural areas, providing fixed-interest mortgage financing for those unable to obtain credit elsewhere. The USDA's housing loan program offers supervised credit counseling to borrowers in rural areas, with benefits in low-income regions. Loans are subsidized with a graduated interest rate, providing 100% financing for up to 33 years. Borrowers must be very-low income to qualify. The USDA's housing loan program offers subsidized loans for low-income borrowers in rural areas. Borrowers must be very-low income or low-income to qualify, with funding ranging from $840.1 million to $1.14 billion annually. Loan guarantees are provided to private lenders for low- and moderate-income families to purchase housing. The USDA's housing loan program provides subsidized loans for low-income borrowers in rural areas. Private lenders are incentivized to offer 30-year mortgages to rural residents with incomes between 80% and 115% of the median county income. The government guarantees 90% of the loan principal, with no down payment requirement. Funding for loan authorization has increased annually, reaching $24.0 billion in FY2016. The USDA's housing loan program provides loan and grant assistance to very-low and low-income homeowners for housing repairs and improvements. Grants cover costs such as repairing roofs, providing toilet facilities, and installing water and sewer services. The program became self-funding in FY2011 and does not require budget authority for loan authorization. Loan subsidies increased annually, reaching $24.0 billion in FY2016. Financing: Loans up to $20,000 and grants up to $7,500 available for very low-income rural residents. Eligibility: Loans for those who own and occupy a dwelling in need of repair and cannot obtain affordable credit elsewhere. Grants limited to elderly homeowners (age 62+) with incomes 50% or less of the median in their area. Grant funds for removal of health or safety hazards. Funding: Loan authorization amounts for FY2005-FY2016 listed. Loan subsidies provided. The program provides loans and grants for housing assistance to farm laborers. Funding amounts for loan subsidies and housing assistance grants from FY2005 to FY2016 are listed. It is the only nationwide program of its kind. Loans and grants are provided to buy, build, improve, or repair housing for farm labor, including aquaculture and on-farm processing workers. Section 516 grants finance off-farm rental housing for low-wage farm workers. The 2008 farm bill expanded the program to include aquaculture and commodity processing workers. Financing includes direct loans with a 1% interest rate and grants covering up to 90% of development costs. Eligibility criteria include farm workers leasing Section 514/516 housing. Loans and grants cover up to 90% of development costs for farm workers leasing Section 514/516 units. Eligibility criteria require recipients to be U.S. citizens or permanent residents with the majority of their income from farm work. Funding for loan authorization ranges from $21.4 million to $38.1 million annually, with a portion allocated for grants. The program provides funding through loans and grants to help very-low- and low-income rural Americans reduce home ownership costs by using "sweat equity." Nonprofit organizations and local governments can receive grant funds to provide technical assistance for families building their homes. Future homeowners use Section 502 direct loans to finance mortgages and reduce costs by 10%-15% through their labor. Statutory Authority: Title V, Section 523 (b)(1)(A) of the Housing Act of 1949; 42 U.S.C. The program provides grants and loans to nonprofit organizations to develop building sites for low- and moderate-income participants in the Self-Help Housing Program. Funding for the program has ranged from $25.0 million to $41.9 million annually from FY2005 to FY2016. Eligibility criteria include low income (50%-80% of area median family income). The Self-Help Housing Program provides loans to nonprofit organizations for developing building sites for low- and moderate-income participants. The loans have a 3% interest rate and are repaid when the properties are sold. Funding for the program ranged from $2.3 million to $10 million annually from FY2005 to FY2016. Eligibility criteria include acquiring and developing sites for housing constructed by the self-help method. The Section 524 program provides loans for acquiring and developing sites for low- or moderate-income families. Loans bear market interest rates and have been funded annually from FY2005 to FY2016. The program is self-funding and supports nonprofit groups and Indian tribes. The Section 533 program provides grants for repairing houses of low- and very-low-income rural residents, as well as for rehabilitating rental properties for low-income families. Grants are limited to $15,000 per unit, with funding ranging from $8.8 million in FY2005 to $0 in FY2014. The Section 515 rental housing program provides housing for the poor through 50-year, 1% loans and rental assistance. Tenants pay a maximum of 30% of their income towards rent and utilities. The program offers four variations of the loan program and utilizes a public-private partnership for financing. Financing: Public-private partnership offers 1% interest loans for affordable rental complexes in rural areas. Eligibility for low-income families. Funding: Loan authorization ranges from $28.4 million to $99.9 million annually. Loan subsidies budget authority ranges from $10.3 million to $46.7 million annually. The program provides loan guarantees for construction, acquisition, and rehabilitation of multifamily housing for low- to moderate-income residents. It offers 90% loan guarantees to certified lenders and covers 97% loan-to-value ratios for the nonprofit sector. Eligibility criteria include very-low- to moderate-income households, elderly, or disabled persons with income not exceeding 115% of the median income of the surrounding area. Loan authorization ranges from $97.2 million to $129.0 million annually. The program provides loan guarantees for multifamily housing for low- to moderate-income residents, with loan authorization ranging from $97.2 million to $129.0 million annually. Rental Assistance is project-based assistance used in conjunction with loan/grant programs to help rural households with housing costs. The program provides rental assistance for RHS-financed projects, ensuring tenants pay no more than 30% of their income for rent. The subsidy indirectly benefits tenants through lower rent payments. Funding for rental assistance has increased over the years, reaching $1.2 billion in FY2016. The RHS program offers loans and grants for low-income borrowers to purchase innovative housing units. The goal is to increase affordable rural housing through new construction approaches. Funding for the demonstration program is capped at $10 million per fiscal year. Eligibility criteria ensure the health and safety of the population in the demonstration areas. Funding is reserved through other RHS programs. The Community Facilities loan and grant program, administered by RHS, supports essential community facilities in rural areas with a population of 20,000 or less. Funding is allocated to state rural development offices, where state directors set priorities particular to their state's rural needs. The program also supports a rural community development initiative and an economic impact initiative. The Community Facilities program (Section 6006) provides technical assistance and training to help communities identify and plan facility needs. Loans are available for constructing, enlarging, or improving essential facilities in rural areas and towns under 20,000 population. Applicants must show inability to secure funding at reasonable rates in the commercial market. Health and public safety projects have priority. Interest rates are based on median family income, ranging from 4.5% to 5.375%. Guaranteed loans involve negotiation between lender and borrower. The Community Facilities program provides loans for essential facilities in rural areas and towns under 20,000 population. Priority is given to health and public safety projects. Loan authorization levels for direct loans in recent years have ranged from $290.5 million to $2.2 billion. Loan authorization levels for direct loans in recent years have ranged from $290.5 million to $2.2 billion, with subsidy levels decreasing from $29.5 million in FY2005 to $0 in FY2012 onwards. Guaranteed loan authorization levels have fluctuated between $194.9 million and $148.3 million, with subsidy levels varying from $6.8 million to $3.5 million. Grants totaling $5.0 million in FY2012, $3.6 million in FY2013, $3.8 million in FY2014, $3.5 million in FY2015, and $3.5 million in FY2016 were authorized under the 1996 farm bill (P.L. 104-127). These grants are used with direct loans to provide essential community facilities to low-income communities. Eligible applicants include public bodies, nonprofit organizations, and special purpose districts serving communities of 20,000 or less, with priority given to those of 5,000 or less. The facility must serve areas with incomes below the poverty line or 90% of the state non-metropolitan median household income. The Community Facilities Grant Program funds projects for Native American community development, child care centers, and economic initiatives. Funding amounts vary annually, with additional funds earmarked for communities facing economic hardship and population out-migration. The Community Facilities Grant Program provides grants for capacity-building in housing, community facilities, and economic development for low-income rural communities. Funding amounts vary annually, with grants awarded to qualified intermediaries. Statutory Authority: Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2001. Financing: Competitive grants. The Community Facilities Grant Program, authorized by the Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act of 2001, provides competitive grants for essential community facilities in rural areas with high unemployment and economic distress. Eligible applicants include public entities, nonprofits, and tribal organizations in rural areas with 20,000 or fewer residents and an unemployment rate above 19.5%. Matching funds are required from non-Federal sources, with funding amounts varying annually. The Rural Development Grant Program offers competitive grants for essential community facilities in rural areas with high unemployment and economic distress. Eligibility criteria include rural areas with 20,000 or fewer residents, an unemployment rate above 19.5%, and a median household income below 90% of the state non-metropolitan median. Funding amounts vary annually, with a focus on creating, expanding, and retaining employment in rural areas. Since the mid-1950s, manufacturing in rural America has provided high-paying employment but now faces competition from developing countries. Many low-skilled manufacturing facilities have moved offshore, leading rural areas to seek new sources of competitive advantage in technologically advanced production. Lack of capital is a significant challenge, but the Rural Development Grant Program offers funding for essential community facilities in rural areas with high unemployment and economic distress. The Rural Business Service (RBS) provides loans, grants, technical, and marketing assistance to help local entrepreneurs start and expand businesses in rural areas. Direct loans are given to various entities that then lend funds to rural businesses and organizations for economic development projects, job creation, and business expansion. The Rural Business Service (RBS) provides loans for community development projects in rural areas, excluding cities with a population of 25,000 or more. The loan authorization for FY2005-FY2016 ranged from $17.4 million to $33.9 million annually. The Rural Business Service (RBS) provides zero-interest loans for RUS borrowers to lend to rural businesses. The loan subsidies for FY2005-FY2016 ranged from $4.1 million to $18.9 million annually, funded through a "cushion-of-credit" account in the U.S. Treasury. Borrowers forward pay on their loans into the account, earning a 5% annual interest rate to leverage the loans. Loans for electric and telephone utilities come from interest earned on a cushion-of-credit account. Loans are made to utilities with current loans with RUS or Rural Telephone Bank, not delinquent on federal debt. Loan authorization for FY2005-FY2016 ranged from $24.3 million to $33.1 million annually. Grants establish a revolving loan fund program for economic development in rural areas. The loan fund provides capital to nonprofit and municipal organizations in rural areas for community facilities promoting job creation, education, training, and medical care. Funds come from interest on borrowers' cushion of credit accounts. Borrowers can make voluntary deposits into the account, accruing interest at 5% annually, to make scheduled loan payments. Eligibility criteria include economic development. The Rural Economic Development Loan and Grant Program provides funding for economic development projects in rural areas. Grants are used for feasibility studies, start-up costs, and incubator projects. Funding amounts vary by fiscal year. Grants are made to fund centers for rural cooperative development to improve economic conditions in rural areas through cooperatives. Grants may be awarded to nonprofit or higher education institutions. Grants under the Rural Economic Development Loan and Grant Program can be used for up to 75% of project costs, with the applicant contributing 25% from non-federal sources. The program also reserves 20% of funding for cooperative development centers serving socially disadvantaged groups. Eligibility includes nonprofit institutions and higher education institutions. The Rural Cooperative Grants program, funded annually, provides information on sustainable agricultural practices to farmers and rural users. Established in 1985, it was transferred between the Department of Interior's Fish and Wildlife Service and USDA's Rural Business Service. The ATTRA program at the University of Arkansas provides information and assistance on sustainable agricultural practices. It is funded through a cooperative agreement and offers grants to farmers and ranchers to increase the value of agricultural commodities. Funding for the program varies annually. The ATTRA program at the University of Arkansas offers grants to farmers and ranchers to increase the value of agricultural commodities. The program was reauthorized through 2012 in the 2008 farm bill and is funded through competitive grants. Funding for the program varies annually, with funding amounts ranging from $3.9 million to $20.7 million per year. The Rural Business Investment Program, authorized by the 2002 farm bill and amended in the 2008 and 2014 farm bills, allows limited liability companies to make equity capital investments in rural businesses. The program operates under a memorandum of agreement with the U.S. Department of Commerce's Small Business Administration. Funding for the program was initially set at $50 million, but the 2014 farm bill reduced it to $20 million annually from FY2014-2018. The Rural Business Investment Program, authorized by the 2002 farm bill and amended in the 2008 and 2014 farm bills, provides funding to eligible farmers, ranchers, and small businesses for renewable energy purchases. Funding was initially set at $50 million but reduced to $20 million annually from FY2014-2018. Financing options include direct loans, guaranteed debentures, and grants. Eligibility criteria require designation as a Rural Business Company. The Rural Energy for America Program (REAP) provides funding to farmers, ranchers, and small businesses for renewable energy systems. It was reauthorized in the 2008 farm bill. Eligibility criteria include agricultural producers with 50% of income from agricultural operations and small businesses in rural areas. Funding includes loans and grants, with $23.0 million authorized per fiscal year. The Rural Microentrepreneur Assistance Program (RMAP) provides grant funding. Funding amounts varied from $22.8 million in FY2007 to $7.6 million in FY2016, with a mix of loan authorizations and subsidies. The Rural Microentrepreneur Assistance Program (RMAP) provides grant funding to microenterprise development organizations (MDOs) and microlenders in rural areas. MDOs can also make fixed-interest rate micro-loans up to $50,000 for rural microenterprises. Grants are available for training and services for MDOs supporting rural microenterprises. Financing includes fixed-interest direct loans and grants, with a maximum loan amount of $500,000 to microlenders and grants up to 25% of the total outstanding balance of microloans for MDOs. Matching funding of up to 15% is required from MDOs. The Rural Microentrepreneur Assistance Program (RMAP) provides grant funding to microenterprise development organizations (MDOs) and microlenders in rural areas. MDOs must provide matching funding of up to 15% of the total grant amount. Funds are used to capitalize rural revolving loan funds for making microloans to microenterprise borrowers. Mandatory funding of $4 million was provided in FY2010-FY2011 and $3 million in FY2012, with discretionary funding of $40 million each year FY2009-FY2012. Loan guarantees were authorized in the 2008 farm bill. The new program authorizes loan guarantees for locally and regionally produced foods, prioritizing underserved rural and urban areas. Eligibility criteria include foods marketed within 400 miles of the product's origin or within the state. Underserved areas lack access to affordable, healthy foods like fresh fruits and vegetables in grocery stores or direct markets. Financing is provided through the Business and Industry loan program. The 2014 farm bill authorizes the Healthy Food Financing Initiative (HFFI) in USDA to support locally and regionally produced foods. The program is operated through Community Development Financial Institutions and prioritizes job creation and retention. Funding of $125 million is authorized but has not been allocated yet. The Rural Business Program, administered by RBS, supports business development, training, and retention. The Rural Business Program, administered by RBS, supports business development, training, and retention through various funding lines. The program finances business and industry projects in rural areas, including acquisition, construction, expansion, and repair. Loan funds can be used for land purchase, supplies, materials, and start-up costs. Eligible applicants include individuals and various organizations. The Rural Business Program, administered by RBS, supports business development in rural areas through various funding lines. Eligible applicants include individuals and organizations. The program offers subsidized interest loans and guarantees for loans provided by lenders, with maximum guaranteed loan amounts ranging from $5 million to $25 million. Under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, loans scoring at least 55 points based on loan priority variables receive a 90% guarantee. Under the Rural Business Program, loans scoring at least 55 points based on priority variables receive a 90% guarantee. Borrowers must be unable to obtain credit elsewhere at reasonable rates. Eligible projects include those that save existing jobs, improve businesses, or create permanent jobs. Ineligible projects include golf courses, race tracks, and gambling operations. Funding for direct loans has not been provided since FY2001. Loan authorization levels for guaranteed loans have varied from $678.1 million in FY2005 to $993 million in FY2009. Grants are provided to public bodies, nonprofit organizations, Indian tribes, and cooperatives for training and technical assistance to rural businesses, economic planning for rural communities, or training for rural entrepreneurs or economic development officials. Funding levels have varied over the years, with FY2016 showing $919.8 million with a loan subsidy of $35.8 million. The Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act of 1972 provides competitive grants to public bodies, nonprofit corporations, tribal groups, and cooperatives in rural areas. Funding for the grants has ranged from $2.1 million to $3.1 million annually. The grants aim to support small businesses, rural distance learning networks, educational instruction, job training, and technical assistance for rural communities. The Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act of 1972 provides competitive grants for technical assistance and training in rural communities to improve passenger transportation services. Priority is given to rural areas with a population of 25,000 or less, as well as communities with a large proportion of low-income residents and high unemployment. Funding for the program has ranged from $2.1 million to $3.1 million annually, with supplemental funding under ARRA adding $19.7 million. The Business Development Grants program was newly authorized in the 2014 farm bill. The Business Development Grants program, authorized in the 2014 farm bill, combines functions of previous grants to support rural business development. Up to 10% of funds can be used for various activities like identifying business opportunities and providing technical assistance, while the rest can support projects such as financing small businesses and rural learning programs. The Delta Regional Authority (DRA) provides economic assistance to economically distressed counties in eight southern states through loans and grants for community projects. The program is funded through competitive grants and is open to governmental entities, Indian tribes, and non-profit entities. Funding for the program was $26.6 million in FY2014 and $24.0 million in both FY2015 and FY2016. The Delta Regional Authority (DRA) provides economic assistance to economically distressed counties in eight southern states through loans and grants for community projects. The program is funded through competitive grants, with at least 75% of funds invested in distressed areas. Approximately half of the funds are for transportation and infrastructure improvement. Funding for the program has ranged from $1 million in FY2005 to $3 million in FY2016. The economic development policy focuses on providing infrastructure like railroads, roads, telegraph lines, electricity, and telephones to rural areas with federal support. The Rural Electrification Act of 1936 was crucial for rural utilities. Today, the Rural Utilities Service administers programs for rural electrification, telecommunications, water infrastructure, health service delivery, and broadband telecommunication resources. Congress funds these new rural utilities due to great distances and sparse populations. The Rural Utilities Service provides funding for rural utilities such as telephones and electrical generation. Loans are offered to expand and maintain rural electric infrastructure, with interest rates tied to economic conditions. Borrowers must obtain half of their capital needs from the private sector, and there are three interest rate levels for RUS-financed systems. Additionally, RUS offers direct loans through various financial institutions with low default rates. The Federal Finance Bank offers loans for rural electrification based on the Treasury rate plus 1/8%. The program has a zero subsidy cost due to a low default rate. Loans are typically for 35 years and secured by the borrower's electric system assets. Over 90% of loans under the RUS electrification account are from FFB. Eligibility criteria include electricity producers and transmitters serving rural populations. Funding levels for FFB loans were $4.32 billion in FY2005. Funding for Federal Finance Bank loans: FY2005: $4.32 billion; FY2016: $5.5 billion. Subsidies for loans: FY2005: $5.0 million; FY2016: $0. Guaranteed underwriting program: $750 million loan authorization for FY2016, no subsidy required. Program provides loans for infrastructure improvement, including broadband service in rural areas. RUS lends directly to rural telecommunication systems. The Rural Utilities Service (RUS) provides direct loans and guarantees for rural telecommunication systems, including broadband service in rural areas. Loans are available at different levels based on income thresholds, with funding levels authorized annually. The Rural Utilities Service (RUS) provides financial assistance to rural community facilities such as schools, libraries, hospitals, and medical centers through a program that helps them obtain advanced telecommunications for health and educational services. The program is authorized by the Food, Agriculture, Conservation, and Trade Act of 1990. Funding for the program includes competitive grants with grant funding ranging from $29.7 million to $37.7 million annually. The Rural Telephone Bank (RTB) was established to provide rural telephone systems access to capital. It had a capital structure with three classes of stock: Class A, Class B, and Class C. Class A stock was issued in exchange for $600 million of capital. The RTB was privatized through sales of Class A stock. Final liquidation payments were made to Class A and B shareholders in 2007. The Rural Telephone Bank (RTB) was privatized through sales of Class A stock, with final liquidation payments made to Class A and B shareholders in 2007. The financing for rural systems depends on the borrower's financial condition, with most eligible for loans at a hardship rate of 5%. New telecommunication technologies require infrastructure capable of carrying complex signals at faster speeds, posing challenges for rural areas due to higher costs per user compared to urban areas. The Rural Telephone Bank (RTB) was privatized through sales of Class A stock, with final liquidation payments made to Class A and B shareholders in 2007. RUS provides loans and grants to support acquisition/construction of broadband facilities in under-served rural areas. Eligibility criteria target rural, economically challenged communities for broadband transmission services to various organizations.
